name: Sergi Gomez
post: "Can you please create a new dimension for this metric?"This is one of the most frequent requests that data teams get from data consumers. A simple but repetitive one that fills our backlog at the end of the day. The consequence? Data teams get overloaded with those "quick changes" and they can't focus on higher-impact tasks.Data consumers should be able to make those simple changes themselves. But if we try to force them to adopt SQL/dbt, it won't fly, trust me. Yes, they will give it a try but, after a few weeks, they'll get back to creating a new JIRA ticket.If we want this habit to stick, we have to make it easier, and, whenever possible, allow them to work on the tool that they already use Every, Single, Day: Excel / Google Sheets.Google Sheets are the ideal medium when we need to create a new dimension that is simply the mapping from an existing one.Example: "I want a new dimension called Product Category as a higher-level dimension of Product Name"I constantly see data models full of "CASE WHEN X THEN Y". Please, don't do that!Instead, the following is a very very simple but efficient method to do it much faster and that provides way more control & autonomy for end users:(I'll use the example of Product Category -> Product Name for sake of illustration):1- Create a new table on Google Sheets with all Product Name values - Note: You should as well include all Primary Keys (e.g. product ID) to avoid issues such as duplicates. 2- Create a new column (Product Category) and ask the data consumer to do the mapping.3- Integrate this table into your Data Warehouse (DW) using Airbyte. Making this connection on Airbyte has a bit of heavy lifting (service accounts, keys...), and there may be tools that make it easier, (maybe we should try Portable, Ethan Aaron? 🙂 ). Note that you won't need Airbyte if you use BigQuery as DW. BigQuery already provides seamless Google Sheets integration. 4- Add the new dimensions to the corresponding dbt model with a simple join operation, and run the dbt models - (run some tests to make sure there aren't duplicates!)Voilà, the new dimension is available on the BI. And the best thing: If data consumers want to make any changes to this dimension, they can do it themselves and it will be automatically updated on the BI! 😍 Watch the demo if you want to see how to do it👇. There is a big list of examples for which this method is very handy:- Create a new dimension that indicates the validity of an order based on other dimensions, so end users can later on filter out non-valid orders for your Revenue metrics 😉 - Create a new dimension that gives a name to an identifier (i.e. a number). So instead of distributor_id you can have the distributor name - ...At Saivo, we love making data teams' life easier by empowering data consumers to do these simple tasks themselves. It's a win-win formula.Would love to get your feedback! #nocode #dbt #datanalytics #businessanalyst

name: Beatriz Zatarain Durán
post: El análisis de datos está revolucionando el mundo de la sostenibilidad🚀El análisis de #datos es una herramienta tan poderosa que puede ayudar a abordar una amplia variedad de problemas sociales y ambientales, incluyendo la #sostenibilidad. Al recopilar y analizar grandes cantidades de información, es posible identificar tendencias y patrones que pueden ayudar a tomar decisiones informadas sobre cómo abordar los desafíos de sostenibilidad a nivel local y global.Por ejemplo, el análisis de datos está ayudando a mejorar la sostenibilidad en el sector de la agricultura de una manera increíble. Las granjas están utilizando tecnologías como sensores, drones y aprendizaje automático para recopilar datos sobre las condiciones climáticas, el suelo y las prácticas de cultivo. Al analizar esta información, los agricultores pueden optimizar sus prácticas de cultivo para reducir el uso de agua y fertilizantes, mejorar la calidad del suelo y aumentar la eficiencia energética en la producción de alimentos.Además, al tener una visión más clara de las prácticas sostenibles y no sostenibles, los agricultores y las empresas agrícolas pueden tomar medidas para mejorar su huella de carbono y contribuir a la lucha contra el cambio climático.En resumen, el análisis de datos es una herramienta esencial para abordar los desafíos de sostenibilidad en un mundo cada vez más interconectado y en constante evolución. Al utilizar los datos de manera efectiva, podemos trabajar juntos para construir un futuro más sostenible para todos.

name: Samaneh Dehghanpour
post: How to get ahead of 90% of UX portfolios (Summary)👇I've been collecting tips and tricks that will help a portfolio stand out for the past few months on LinkedIn .Here’s a summary of them: 🔶️30-second test:Your case studies should be scannable and visually appealing enough to help the hiring managers reach a conclusion about your skills in under 30 seconds.  🔶️A two-version portfolioSome hiring managers want short, scannable case studies, while others demand as much detail as possible. You better make two versions of every case study to meet both requirements.🔶️High-fidelity design position:Put clear and high-resolution images of your high-fidelity design at the top of your case studies, not towards the end of it. Make a good first impression.  🔶️Gifs over videos:It's better to upload gifs of your clickable prototype rather than a video. It requires one click less to show your design.  🔶️Productize your portfolio:Treat your portfolio like a product design project. Your target audience is recruiters and hiring managers. Now go and do the whole design process, from research to the end product.  🔶️No boring design framework:Don't repeat yourself by writing your portfolio as a copy-paste of a step-by-step design framework. Instead, try answering these questions to write about your unique experience:+How did you measure success?+What was the most difficult part?+How did you contribute to the project?+How did target users interact with the product?+What would you do differently if you wanted to do the project all over again? Special thanks to Colton Schweitzer; Many of these tips it's what I've learned from him about writing portfolios.What would you add to the list?#ux #design #productdesign #research #recruiters #hiring #uxdesign #uidesign #uxui #userexperience #userinterfacedesign #userexperiencedesign #uxresearch #designers #uxportfolio #portfoliodesign

name: Santiago Fuentes
post: HOW CAN WE IMPROVE CRITICAL THINKING?While analyzing data, "the goal is to turn information into insights and in order to create insights about the right things, we must ask the right questions.If you want to be a good critical thinker, you need to remember that it’s all about practice. Like any habit, there are certain muscles you need to flex over time, and here are some basic drills for it:1. IDENTIFICATIONThe first step is to identify the situation or problem. Once you have a clear picture of that, and the factors that may influence it, you can begin to dive deeper into it and its potential solutions.How to Improve: When faced with a new situation, question, or scenario, stop to take a mental picture of how things are stacked up.2. ASK QUESTIONS“It is better to debate a question without settling it than to settle a question without debating it” — Joseph JoubertLearn to question everything. It’s very easy to accept things at face value, but that’s a sign of a lazy mind.How to Improve: You can start by asking the following questions:What do you already know?How do you know that?What seems to be the reason for this happening?What are you trying to prove, disprove, demonstrate, critique, and support?What are you overlooking?You should continually go back to these basic questions you asked when you set out to solve the problem. These types of questions urge you to get right to the core of a problem, examining it for simple solutions before assuming its complexities.3. BE AWARE OF YOUR MENTAL PROCESSBeing a good critical thinker requires you to accept that you have biases. Although even the best critical thinkers will never be entirely bias-free, you need to learn to look out for them.How to Improve: Make a habit of asking yourself what you’re assuming and why you’re assuming that, and check for things like stereotyping.Becoming more mindful of your own biases is the first step to rewriting these parts of your thinking.4. ADJUST YOUR PERSPECTIVEGood critical thinkers do their best to be neutral with respect to their own beliefs and thoughts, spotting biases and prejudices and then correcting them.How to Improve: Think of yourself as a judge. You have to evaluate both sides of an argument, but you also need to keep in mind the biases each side may possess.When evaluating information, ask yourself these questions:Whom will this benefit?Does the source have an agenda?Is the source ignoring, overlooking, or leaving out information?Is this source using unnecessary language to change an audience’s mind?"Check out the rest of the critical thinking steps in the full article by Angelica Dietzel linked in the comments.#data #thinkautonomous #ai4good #pensamientocrítico

Here you should also track your Train/Test splits. At this stage you should also save all important metrics that relate to Datasets - Feature Distribution etc.3️⃣ Model Parameters (e.g. model type, hyperparameters) together with Model Performance metrics.4️⃣ Model Artifact Location.5️⃣ Machine Learning Pipeline is an artifact itself - track information about who and when triggered it. Pipeline ID etc.✅ Code: Everything is code - you should version and track it. When a Trained Model Artifact is saved to a Model Registry there should always be a 1 to 1 mapping of previously saved Model Metadata to The Artifact which was outputted to The Model Registry: ➡️  Model Registry should have a convenient user interface in which you can compare metrics of different Experiment versions.➡️  Model Registry should have a capability that allows change of Model State with a single click of a button. Usually it would be a change of state between Staging and Production. Finally: 6️⃣  Model Tracking System should be integrated with the Model Deployment System. Once a model state is changed to Production, The System triggers a Deployment Pipeline that will deploy a new model version and perform a decommission of the old one. This will vary depending on the type of deployment. Model Tracking System containing these properties helps in the following way: ➡️  You will be able to understand how a Model was built and repeat the experiment.➡️  You will be able to share experiments with other experts involved.➡️  You will be able to perform rapid, controlled experiments.➡️  The system allows safe rollbacks to any Model Version.➡️  Such Self-Service System would remove friction between ML and Operations experts.Would you add something? 👇-------- 👋 I am Aurimas.I will help you 𝗟𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗹 𝗨𝗽 in #MLOps, #MachineLearning, #DataEngineering, #DataScience and overall #Data space.𝗙𝗼𝗹𝗹𝗼𝘄 𝗺𝗲 and hit 🔔𝗗𝗼𝗻’𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿𝗴𝗲𝘁 𝘁𝗼 𝗹𝗶𝗸𝗲 👍, 𝘀𝗵𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁!Join a growing community of Data Enthusiasts by subscribing to my 𝗡𝗲𝘄𝘀𝗹𝗲𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿: https://lnkd.in/e_kkkGei

name: Valtteri Heinilä
post: We did it! We just cycled from Helsinki to Singapore!• 21 countries• 15400km• 245 daysWhy in the world would we cycle to Singapore?We wanted to go on an adventure. Alvari had cycled from Helsinki to France and liked it. We looked at a map and Singapore seemed like a nice peninsula at the very end of continental Asia. We wanted to break daily routines, to do some house cleaning of our minds, to slow time down, to rid ourselves of living for the future, to challenge ourselves both phyiscally and mentally. And we did just that!Words fall short to capture the emotions of yesterday, so here are some effable learnings from life on the saddle:1. The best days are the ones that seem worst in the moment. This goes for this trip and my previous jobs. The days where shit hits the fan are the ones in which you learn the most and that you will later cherish. 2.  Don't consume experiences and hope for things to play out in a hopeful way, but create your own adventures with the resources you have available and make things happen.  3. Expect nothing. Focus on the process, not the outcome. 4. Finland is quite a special country where things really work well and the quality of life is extremely high. I easily fall into routines and comfort, so remember to continue to challenge yourself and don't fall into the traps of comfort and pleasure.  5. Stay active. The most physical days seem to provide the most insight and feelings of tranquility. 6. It doesn't really help what you want to do in the future, just give 100% to what you are doing now and it will open doors for you later on. Less planning, more living.  Thanks for all the support!Cheers,ValluFollow our more deeper reflections on ig: https://lnkd.in/gNqBp9tM

post: As a Data Analyst, I use a lot of functions in Excel/Google SheetsAnd pivot tables are NOT one of them Here are the top 5 that I use most often...- SUMIFS: This function sums a range based on conditions- COUNTUNIQUEIFS: This is a great way to get a count of values like emails based on conditions- XLOOKUP: Normally, you don't need the whole row of data so you pick and choose what you would like with this!- IMPORTRANGE: Never do double work! name: Juliana Rabbi - Remote Work Coach
post: Most of the job seekers I spoke with in the past 2 weeks are making the same mistake:❌  OverthinkingBy definition, overthinking is “putting too much time into thinking about or analyzing (something) in a way that is more harmful than helpful”.✳️ And why is it a mistake?Overthinking has different stages. It will probably start with you thinking about your career, being cautious and responsible about any changes, planning how to transition for a better job, being responsible with your current company and the financial commitments you have already made, choosing well the next company, etc.➡️ So, until a certain point, thinking about your career means that you care about it - and that is fine.⚠️ When you remain for too long thinking about a career change and not taking any action, without even realizing, you move from thinking to overthinking.▪️ “It’s not the right moment to start the #jobsearch yet”▪️ “If by June this year nothing change in my company, then I will start looking for a new #job”▪️ “There are so many layoffs happening that maybe it’s not the best time to change jobs”If you told yourself one of the phrases above recently, and you are not yet taking actions to improve your #career, you are probably overthinking.🔸 I am concerned about overthinking because the final result is that you feel paralyzed and delay your dreams. You settle for less. You start believing that there is nothing better out there for you, and that the only option you have is to remain where you are now.🎯 How to change that? Make the first step.Do at least one thing to break the situation and help you to move towards the right direction.One step leads to the next step. name: David García Lozano
post: La diferencia entre SER, y PARECER.Quiero compartir una experiencia perso-profesional que viví ayer, y que me hizo reflexionar.Ayer era mi cumpleaños.Un año antes, yo colaboraba con una empresa X, y recuerdo perfectamente el día de mi cumpleaños, porque lo cogí de vacaciones, avisando con más de un mes de antelación, beneficio que esa empresa otorgaba, sin descontar el día de tu saldo de vacaciones anual.Ese mismo dia (un lunes) entorno a las 11 de la mañana, me llama la que era mi jefa, preguntando que donde estaba, que porque no estaba en la oficina, a lo que respondí, que estaba disfrutando de mi día de cumpleaños, el cual habia sido aprobado por ella misma, y que ademas, en mi agenda pública se podia ver que estaba off.La conversación fué breve. Ella transmitió su indignación y enfado, de no muy buenas maneras, con frases como "con la que tenemos encima nose como te coges el día".Por dar contexto a esta afirmación, cabe mencionar que en ese momento, yo llevaba tiempo asumiendo tareas de 1 HRBP,1 HR manager, y 1 becario que salieron, y estaban siendo repuestosLa conversación acabo con un "ya hablaremos" y por supuesto, sin una felicitación de cumpleaños.Minutos mas tarde, me llamó el nivel jerarquico superior a mi jefa directa, para transmitirme también su indignacion por no estar presente, la decepción por el bajo rendimiento los meses recientes (Primera noticia que tuve de este feedback), e invitandome a una reunión esa misma semana donde "se revisarian mis condiciones y rendimiento". Obvio, tampoco hubo felicitación 😅.Pues bien:Un año mas tarde, colaboro en otra empresa (que no da el día de tu cumpleaños OFF como beneficio), y tengo otra jefa, basada en Portugal.En el día de mi cumpleaños, me escribió por teams para decirme que "iba a tope, pero que no queria dejar de desearme un feliz día", pero esque al acabar su jornada (mis 19) me llamó a mi teléfono personal, para preguntarme que tal habia pasado el día, y felicitarme una vez mas, de la manera mas cercana y personal, sin mencionar una palabra sobre trabajo, sabiendo que teniamos reunion al día siguiente.Fue en ese momento, cuando recordé todo lo ocurrido un año atrás.Fue en ese momento cuando me sentí enormemente agradecido, valororado, afortunado.Fue en ese momento cuando dije "¡Jo que guay!"Fue en ese momento cuando comprendí la diferencia entre "PARECER" una empresa que cuida a sus empleados, y "SER" una empresa que cuida a sus empleados. Y puede ocurrir que tu empresa no tenga una cultura de "priorizar o cuidar" al empleado, pero tu, como lider, como manager, pero sobre todo como buen ser humano, tienes el deber y la responsabilidad de cuidar de tu equipo.Si alguna vez tienes que elegir entre ser un buen profesional, y ser una buena persona. ELIGE SER BUENA PERSONA.No existen los buenos lideres, con malos valores.Anyway, a pesar de "currar", tuve un día maravilloso 😋 MUITO OBRIGADO

name: Danny Butvinik
post: In data science and machine learning, the Expectation Maximization (EM) algorithm can be used to estimate latent variables, like those that come from mixture distributions (we know that they came from a mixture but don’t know from which specific distribution). The EM algorithm is a specialized approach for Maximum Likelihood Estimation (MLE) problems. It has some nice features, like not needing to know the size of each step and always converging to a local maximum of the likelihood function under simple conditions. Although MLE and EM can both find the best-fit parameters, the ways they find the models are very different.  MLE gathers all the information first, then uses that information to build the most likely model.  EM makes guesses about the parameters to account for the missing data. It then changes the model to make the guesses and the real data fit together. The basic steps for the algorithm are: 1. The model parameters are guessed first, and a probability distribution is made. This is sometimes called the “E-Step” for the “expected” distribution. 2. Newly observed data is fed into the model. 3. The probability distribution from the E-step is tweaked to include the new data. This is sometimes called the M-step. 4. Steps 2-4 are repeated until stability (i.e., a distribution that doesn’t change from the E-step to M-step is reached.) The EM algorithm always converges, even though it might converge to bad local extrema. The expectation-maximization algorithm can be used: (*) to fill in their missing data in a sample.(*) as the basis for the unsupervised learning of clusters. (*) to estimate the parameters of the Hidden Markov Model (HMM). (*) to discover the values of latent variables. Limitation The EM algorithm can be very slow, even on the fastest computer. It works best when you only have a small percentage of missing data and the dimensionality of the data isn’t too large. The E-step moves more slowly as the number of dimensions goes up. The E-step may move very slowly if you have data with many dimensions, as the procedure approaches a local maximum. Image: Author (inspired by Victor Lavrenko)#machinelearning #datascience

name: Juliana Rabbi - Remote Work Coach
post: How to be successful in your next pre-screening interview🔹 Do you know what a pre-screening interview is? It’s normally the first conversation you have with someone inside the company you want to work for. It has a more informal tone and it will be short (between 5 - 20 minutes).It can be so informal that some #jobseekers “forget” it is still an #interview and don’t prepare well for that!🔹 Why do pre-screening interviews happen?Because the company wants to confirm if you meet the job requirements and if you are available. It’s a way to “double-check” if you are a good fit for the job before they spend more time doing a long interview.🔹 What will happen after?If your pre-screening interview goes well, the company will invite you for a formal #jobinterview.So, remember that this is a decisive part of the recruitment process!🔹 What if the pre-screening interview goes wrong?Well… unfortunately you will be eliminated from the recruitment process. The recruiter will choose another candidate.In my new YouTube video, I explain in detail all you need to know about pre-screening interviews, in order to better succeed and move to the next steps of the process.** Link to the full video in the comments.#jobsearch

post: ➡️  3 Gründe Airpods zu tragen, auch wenn sie nicht aufgeladen sindApple ist ein Lifestyle, dem jeder gute Startup Gründer angehört.Aber warum sollten wir immer Airpods tragen?Es geht nicht um ihre Audioqualität, Calls oder Ladelaufzeit.Es geht darum Statements abzugeben: 1. Ich bin wichtiger als du.Du willst mit mir reden? Mir egal! Ich arbeite an etwas wichtigem und DU bist nicht wichtig genug um mich zu stören - Pech gehabt!Gut, ich bin jetzt nicht im Call sondern höre Cardi B. Und gut, ich bin auch nicht in Agicap sondern plane meine nächsten Gym Session in Excel. Aber zumindest solltest du SPÜREN, was ich von dir halte - und merken, dass du meine Zeit nicht wert bist.2. Ich arbeite IMMER“Der ist bestimmt im Call”, denken sie.Und das sollen sie auch.Es geht im Arbeitsleben nicht darum was du leistest - es geht um RESPEKT!Und Respekt bekommt man dafür, dass man Vollgas gibt.Bzw: Dass es so aussieht, dass man Vollgas gibt.Bzw: Dass man es so aussehen lässt, dass man Vollgas gibt.Die Realität ist immer subjektiv - und busy zu wirken ist essentiell fürs Personal Branding.Was sollen denn sonst die anderen Leute aus Berlin Mitte denken?(Tipp: Wenn jemand fragt, wie es dir geht, antworte mit: "Busy.")3. Apple Gang“Apple ist Mainstream” sagen sie. Falsch! Wir Apple-User sind quasi wie Neo & Morpheus, die gegen die Matrix kämpfen. Wir sind die Wiedergeburt von Steve Jobs, die die Welt voranbringt.Napoleon und Kolumbus würden heute auch AirPods tragen, 100%!Du musst wissen: Wir sind Pioniere. Und schlau. Und haben Kohle.Aber Mainstream sind wir definitiv NICHT!Bonus Tipp:Auch wenn du wirklich mit jemandem im Call bist, der dich nicht sieht, solltest du kurz droppen dass du Airpods trägst.Beispiele:"Warte ich mach mal kurz die AIRPODS rein.""MAN, das Bluetooth von meinen AIRPODS spackt schon wieder rum.""Ich wechsel mal kurz von den AIRPODS auf mein BOSE Headset."Ich hoffe ich konnte euch mit diesen Tipps mal wieder helfen, wie ihr euch als Gründer fühlt wie Elon Musk, ohne so hart dafür arbeiten zu müssen.Und denkt immer daran: AirPods gehören ins Ohr, und nicht in den Auflade-Case!➡️ Was hab ich vergessen, weshalb sollte man IMMER Airpods tragen?

post: Hype, hyperbole!That's the current trajectory the data industry is on.Why?I was just speaking to a COO about the data and digital revolution.He stated it was just overrated and has a tendency to under deliver.We discussed his experiences and guess what like many others there was a litany of tech being rolled out with no real directional motivation.I asked what that meant "directional motivation" and he said that we have a vision in the company, we have a number of corporate objectives and none of the direction of travel really took that into consideration.He was super frustrated!He had been in many meetings where swathes of PowerPoint presentations were thrust at the attendees with too many buzzwords such as AI/IoT/ML.He had interjected many times and wanted to understand how all of it fit back to the purpose. Unfortunately, for him, the CIO was unencumbered and spending his way to "out-teching our rivals" which apparently was something actually stated in a presentation.He also commented on how little value it would provide his operational teams who were struggling with cost, supply chain issues and speed to market.We started to discuss what his thoughts were and whether he had the motivation in himself to stop the money tech train.It was an awkward moment, there was a pause, some silence between us and then a big sigh.He was planning on having it out at the C-Suite and board level.We paused and I could hear his frustrations through the ether.I've not had that candid a conversation about data and tech with someone for a while, where frustrations had got to increasingly alarming levels.I think he just wanted to speak to someone with an external viewpoint.At the same time my frustrations were at boiling point, as I have been seeing this type of approach in many organisations.He said our discussion had been cathartic.I am sure there are many others that are feeling these frustrations from a data and tech perspective.I've said it many times before - data and tech are the enablers for the business strategy. They aren't THE business strategy.Looking at it through the lens of the business is THE most powerful approach companies should take.Having a business-driven data strategy limits the shiny toy syndrome!This is a Friday frustration moment where I ask myself why are we at this point where companies would rather invest in tech instead of doing the hard work around people and process.All of the investments are useless if you can't get those two right. Don't be a follower, lead your company through transformation the hard way which ends in more success.At the end he said he felt better and thanked me for my ear.I ended the call with one question for the C-Suite and Boards:When will you start leading the pack and stop being sheep?Kyle Fred Eddie Bill Malcolm Juan Joe Joti Mark Andrew Afke#data #transformation #strategy #business #datastrategy #tech #digital #success

name: Cristobal Urenda
post: “Security will finally catch up to DevOps to prevent vulnerabilities like Log4j.” What does it mean? Erik Costlow explains: Long story short: Log4Shell vulnerability changed the game. …In the past, developers might have seen this as a security issue. But this time, developers were pulled away from their work to try to find Log4Shell.“Here’s where the shift left philosophy created a problem – organizations often found Log4Shell and patched it somewhere in the development pipeline only to have it reintroduced and appear again in production. Suddenly DevOps and security had to work together.” What’s coming, then? So Costlow predicts that this is the year that security will operate at the speed of DevOps, and DevOps will fully embrace security. This will occur by shifting security left and integrating security into the stack that monitors the operations side. If you want to understand what this new approach to DevOps is about, I invite you to read this article.http://bit.ly/3ScY4E5

name: Jorge Mas Velasco
post: El Bar Pinotxo es uno de los bares más emblemáticos de la Boqueria, un lugar donde la comida, la historia y la tradición se han combinado para crear una experiencia gastronómica única en Barcelona.Sin embargo, después de tantos años de servicio, Juanito, el dueño de Pinotxo, ha decidido traspasar su negocio.Para aquellos que han tenido la suerte de visitar Pinotxo, la experiencia ha sido inolvidable. Desde el momento en que entras en el pequeño bar, te sientes transportado a otro tiempo, un tiempo donde la comida era más que una necesidad básica, era un ritual que se celebraba con la familia y los amigos.Juanito ha sido el corazón y el alma de Pinotxo durante más de cuatro décadas. Desde el primer día en que abrió las puertas de su pequeño bar, Juanito ha sido un #embajador de la gastronomía catalana, presentando a los visitantes de la Boqueria los sabores y los platos tradicionales de la región, como el "cap i pota con garbanzos". Su cocina de mercado, era siempre fresca, auténtica y hecha con amor, y sus clientes no solo eran turistas, sino también Barceloneses que se habían convertido en amigos.Pinotxo no era solo un lugar para comer, era un lugar donde las personas se conectaban. Juanito conocía a sus clientes por su nombre y por sus gustos, y siempre estaba dispuesto a compartir historias y recetas con aquellos que lo deseaban. Muchas celebridades y personalidades también visitaron Pinotxo, pero Juanito siempre trataba a todos con la misma amabilidad y respeto.Juanito no solo ha conquistado paladares sino que ha sabido transmitir su carisma, su sonrisa, su optimismo y su vital energía y pasión que hacia que fuese de los primeros en llegar al mercado, y donde toda su vida ha estado ligado al mercado de la boqueria.En un mundo donde la comida a menudo se trata como una simple mercancía, lugares como Pinotxo y personas como Juanito son una luz brillante, recordándonos que la comida es más que algo que nos mantiene vivos, es algo que nos une, nos hace felices y nos conecta con nuestro pasado y nuestro futuro.En resumen, Juanito y Pinotxo han dejado una huella imborrable en Mercat de la Boqueria  y en la ciudad de Barcelona. Su legado vivirá en la memoria de todos aquellos que han tenido la suerte de visitar su bar y probar su comida. Su trabajo, dedicación y amor por la #gastronomía y por el mercado de la boqueria, han sido una inspiración para muchos, donde marcará un lugar en la historia de la gastronomía mundial.Sólo podemos dar gracias a Juanito, por su gran dedicación y su gran ejemplo. Gracias, Gracias, Gracias!!!😍#pasion #boqueria #gastronomia #energia #cocinademercado

Steps for using predictive analytics in your business: 🌟 Set your goals for using predictive analytics in your business. What do you want to achieve? What outcomes do you want to see?🌟 Define what you need to measure to accurately assess the results of your predictive analytics efforts. Are there any key indicators that will tell you whether your predictions were accurate?🌟 Develop a strategy for how you will use predictive analytics data in order to make informed decisions. How will you use it to improve your business operations?🌟 Train your staff on how to use the data and how it can be helpful in their work. name: Daliana Liu
post: How to find a job during hiring freeze using Linkedin:1. In Linkedin's search bar, type in "data scientist hiring", you see a list of people with "we are hiring" in their job titles. NEVER ask them for a job directly. Do the following before you send a message.2. Research the job roles Check their profile to see if there are links to the roles they are hiring and see if it fits your background. If you can't find it, research similar roles on their company's hiring website.Don't send generic message. It's a waste of their time. Let them know you understand what kind of candidate they are looking for.3. Send a short personalized message"Hi XX, I saw that you are hiring, I have experience in XYZ and I'm interested in the role, can we chat for 15 min to me to learn more about it?"4. Follow upPeople get busy. If they don't reply, follow up after a few days. Create a spreadsheet to track your messages like your 'job search Salesforce'.Maybe after you chat, they are not hiring or they don't think you are a good fit but want to stay connected; follow up after a few months when you feel you are more ready for the role.80% of the success is in the follow up.5. Use the relevant Linkedin headlineMake sure your Linkedin headline is the type of role you are looking for. For example, if your previous role's business title was "finance researcher" but your actual role was like a data scientist in finance.Then, if you are looking for data scientist roles and have the skillset and experience, change your headline to "data scientist", which is easier for recruiters to find you. With the hiring freeze, it's harder to find a job. And just because it's hard, you should be more thoughtful and strategic about networking. Before you send a message, read it and think whether people on the receiving side would like to read it.What are your advice in job search right now?*I write more about data science career at www.dalianaliu.com free to subscribe#datascience #career

name: Dr. Milan Milanović
post: 𝗪𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗶𝘀 𝗛𝗲𝘅𝗮𝗴𝗼𝗻𝗮𝗹 𝗔𝗿𝗰𝗵𝗶𝘁𝗲𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲?Is also known as 𝗣𝗼𝗿𝘁𝘀 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗔𝗱𝗮𝗽𝘁𝗲𝗿𝘀, is a software design pattern coined by Dr. Alistair Cockburn in 2005. It emphasizes separating business logic from external dependencies and allows for a more flexible and maintainable codebase. The idea is to treat the core functionality as the center (hexagon) and the various external dependencies (databases, web services, UI, etc.) as ports that can be connected or disconnected.This kind of architecture is intended to have the application be driven by users, programs, or tests and isolated from external services such as databases. To achieve this, we need to 𝗿𝗲𝗱𝘂𝗰𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗽𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗯𝗲𝘁𝘄𝗲𝗲𝗻 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗼𝘂𝘁𝘀𝗶𝗱𝗲 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗹𝗱 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗰𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗱𝗼𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗻. This means that business logic should be isolated from infrastructure and framework code.The 𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗲𝗹𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁𝘀 of Hexagonal architecture are:🔹 𝗖𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗗𝗼𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗻: The core business logic and entities that define the application's behavior.🔹 𝗔𝗰𝘁𝗼𝗿𝘀: any real-world thing that can interact with a domain. It could be a human or a test. There are two kinds of actors, primary actors who use a domain (user, test), which are the driving side, and secondary actors that provide the functionality needed by the domain, which is the driven side.🔹 𝗔𝗱𝗮𝗽𝘁𝗲𝗿𝘀: The components that allow the application to interact with external systems and dependencies. Primary adapters convert a request from some technology to tech-agnostic requests that the domain can understand (GUI, test), while secondary adapters convert calls from the domain into specific technology (SQL, file system). Adapters are translation layers between the domain and the outside world.🔹 𝗣𝗼𝗿𝘁𝘀: The defined interfaces for communication between the core domain and adapters. There are two types of ports, primary ports specify how the domain can be used, and secondary ones specify what functionality the domain needs.If you want to 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 about Hexagonal architecture:🔸 𝗔𝗹𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗶𝗿’𝘀 𝗼𝗿𝗶𝗴𝗶𝗻𝗮𝗹 𝗽𝗮𝗽𝗲𝗿 on Hexagonal Architecture: https://lnkd.in/daR2MBq8 and live coding session: https://lnkd.in/dJ_uZkdR🔸 𝗣𝗼𝗿𝘁𝘀 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗔𝗱𝗮𝗽𝘁𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝗣𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻, written by Juan Manuel Garrido de Paz: https://lnkd.in/dzU6NTSn🔸 𝗢𝘃𝗲𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗴𝗶𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝗻 𝗢𝗻𝗶𝗼𝗻/𝗛𝗲𝘅𝗮𝗴𝗼𝗻𝗮𝗹 𝗔𝗿𝗰𝗵𝗶𝘁𝗲𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲𝘀 by Victor Rentea: https://lnkd.in/dQ2vsTAn🔸 𝗗𝗗𝗗, 𝗛𝗲𝘅𝗮𝗴𝗼𝗻𝗮𝗹, 𝗢𝗻𝗶𝗼𝗻, 𝗖𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗻, 𝗖𝗤𝗥𝗦 by Herberto Graca: https://lnkd.in/dJi-49Am#technology #softwareengineering #softwaredesign #techworldwithmilan #softwarearchitecture
